availability.p: This is an open access work licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

msContents.summary: Manuscript fiction from the Chinese Cultural Revolution. The text indicates that it is the fifth copy of a text originally colated in 1974 in Nanjing.

objectDesc.p: 13 pages of thin note paper, rebound on the left hand side into a single quire, measuring x times x cm.
The pages are margined and ruled throughout with page numbers starting after the title page.

projectDesc.p: The materials for this project were purchased through the Chinese second hand book platform kongfz.com

correction.p: Cases of misspelled characters have been corrected when the error is clear cut, such as in personal names or some such. All corrections are marked as corr inside choice.

normalization.p: Characters have been simplified in accordance with the official list of simplified Chinese characters promulgated in June 2013 for use in the People's Republic of China. Whenever simlified characters replace full form variants in the original, the substitution uses reg.

punctuation.p: Punctuation is not marked as such and as it appears in the original. Missing punctuation marks are corrected using corr as inline element.

quotation.p: All quotation marks are retained in the text and are represented by appropriate Unicode characters.

segmentation.p: The current transcription ommits line breaks in the main body of the the text.

abstract.p: During the Chinese Cultural Revolution (conventionally dated 1966-1976) the publishing industry had come to a standstill. Resources were allocated only for the publication of officially sanctioned material. Entertainment fiction did not count among this. Throughout the country, however, clandestine intellectual and literary activities took place, including literary salons, underground poetry and unofficial hand-written entertainment fiction. The latter circulated, in particular, among the educated urban youth who were sent to the countryside from late 1968 onwards. Written mostly on thin notepaper, these “flying books” traveled the country in multiple copies and were re-written into multiple often differing versions. Three Times to Nanjing is one of these titles.

orgName.ORGANIZATION: 中央专线电报上报中央
